results.title: North to the sun
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The story of the development of the rich tropical area around Cairns in the northern parts of Queensland. Shows the primary industries of the region including timber, maize and tobacco; its potentialities for development and its attraction as a homeland for newcomers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Martin-Jones and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Noise destroys
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Phillip Mark-Law, John Honey, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1979 film deals with the effects of industrial noise on hearing. Presented as a dramatic short film, the narrative follows the protagonist, Len, as he discovers he is partially deaf due to twenty years of working with loud machines in a factory and goes on a crusade to improve working conditions. The film is directed at employers as well as employees, showing the importance of wearing safety gear and machines being modified or insulated to limit sound production. The film contains light-hearted moments of comedy, as Len goes about convincing his colleagues and management of the significance of the issue.

Produced by the Tasmanian Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Max Cullen, Brian Duhig, Barry Pierce, John Hale, Keith Jarvis, Barrie Muir, Jack Perry, Richard Meredith, Billie Hammerberg, Tony Boden, Kevin Lacey, Don Glover, Tracy Lee, Bob Gunning, Peter Lewis, Matthew Rhodes

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: No strangers here
results.creator_credit: K Sternberg, Dept of Immigration and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Dealing with the problem of assimilation of migrants, the film shows how newcomers to Australia are finding new friends and happiness in the land of their adoption through the co-operation and sympathetic understanding of ordinary citizens. They begin their new life in a country town and through the personal interest of the editor of the newspaper, the newcomers become part of the life of the community.

results.title: Think back: an introduction to safe and efficient patient transfer and object handling
results.creator_credit: Phil Fury, Geoff Crane and Australia. Repatriation Dept.
results.brief_description:
This 1975 film, commissioned by the Australian Repatriation Department, provides instruction on the correct methods of manual handling in order to avoid back injury. The film contains three distinct sections: the first focusing on the principles for lifting heavy objects; the second showing different methods for lifting patients in the hospital; and the third showing methods for manoeuvring heavy loads such as shovelling material and pushing a trolley.

The first section includes animated sections showing the anatomy of the spine and the different types of back injury, including slipped disks, muscle and ligament strain. It then outlines the steps for lifting a heavy load, focusing on a truck driver loading various objects onto the tray of his vehicle.

The second section is directed at hospital staff, as an instructional video for lifting patients correctly. It shows methods of lifting patients up in bed, into a wheelchair and into a bath. Of particular note is the athletic wear (leotards and tracksuits) of the period worn by the nurses and patients in the demonstrations.

The third section shows methods of manual handling in everyday life with correct posture and stability, including shovelling material; pushing a trolley; and lifting a box into the back seat of a car.

A Repatriation Commission Film
Consultant: David Ferguson, Associate Professor in occupational health, the University of Sydney

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: New decimal coin designs
results.brief_description: Designs for Australia’s six new decimal coins prepared by local designer Stuart Devlin, are presented by the Federal Treasurer, Mr. Harold Holt, and a member of the advisory panel on design Mr. Hal Missingham, who worked closely with the designer and helped solve technical problems. The coins feature seven of Australia’s unique fauna- the spiny anteater, lyre-bird, frilled lizard, feather-tailed glider, platypus, kangaroo and emu.

results.title: The Narwhals came
results.brief_description: Shows records of undersea life made by divers in Arctic waters. Includes photography of the Narwhal whale, sought by hunters for its prized ivory tusk.

results.title: The Music makers
results.creator_credit: Maslyn Williams and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Music makers from all over Australia come each year to the National Fitness Council’s Music Camp formerly held at Geelong Grammar School. Some are professional musicians or students of music, others play only in their spare time, but all combine their talents to produce orchestras and chamber music groups. Performances by the players include selections from Handel, Sibelius and Dohnanyi. Photographed by Frank Bagnall.
